Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--Development and Application of a Multi-site Observing Network to Study Mid-latitude Thermospheric Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a 3-year experimental project to be undertaken as part of the Coupling, Energetics and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions (CEDAR) program. The main objective is to install and operate a small network of Fabry-Perot interferometers (FPI) in the central eastern United States. The network will consist of four stations with a site-to-site separation between 350 and 700 km allowing common volume measurements of winds and temperatures in the thermosphere that together provide a regional view of the thermospheric wind structure and dynamics. This includes quantifying the latitudinal and longitudinal extents, propagation direction, and speed of wave events, source regions, and other dynamical quantities that are not possible with current available instrument deployments. Supporting data from available ground-based magnetometers and radars as well as space-based measurements of magnetic fields, ion drifts and auroral precipitation will be used together with a global thermosphere/ionosphere general circulation model to provide a global context for the measurements. In this way, the observations will facilitate breakthrough insights about the dynamics of the thermosphere including the propagation of large-scale disturbances away from the auroral zone and the response of the mid-latitude thermosphere to geomagnetic disturbances. Strategies and algorithms will be developed as part of this project to change the observing strategy in real-time based, for example, upon the local cloud conditions.

The operational experience gained from this network will serve as a proof of concept for a much larger-scale network required for a more complete investigation of thermospheric dynamics. The pilot network will make technological advances in regard to issues such as understanding how to operate the chain as a unit, how to consistently process data in real time, and how to visualize and interpret results from multiple stations. The project is a collaboration between a team of professors at Clemson University, the University of Michigan, and University of Illinois. Deployment and operation of the instruments and the network will provide hands on training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students at each of the universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The effort supported by this award was directed toward the demonstration of what might be achieved with a Fabry-Perot network of observatories aimed at achieving multi-direction measurements of winds and temperatures across the mesoscale dimensions of roughly 1250 km x 1250 km. These line-of-sight measurements are then used to achieve two dimensional maps that help to illustrate the temporal relationships of phase variations of thermospheric wind and temperature. The increase of two orders-of-magnitude in sensitivity afforded by the replacement of the photo-multiplier detector with a low noise high quantum efficiency CCD camera combined with the imaging of the interference pattern over ten orders has made possible the acquisition of high quality data products (wind error of 3 to 5 ms-1, temp error of 10 to 15 K) with a cadence of 15 to 20 measurements per hour. These results have allowed the determination of monthly climatologies that illustrate seasonal and annual variations. These findings have been published in the Journal of Geophysical Research and elsewhere (see list of papers).

     A major finding that emerged from these NATION observations has been the discovery of the double temperature peaks separated by about five hours seen during the night for about 20-30% of the time for all four seasons. This is generally referred to as the MTM (midnight temperature maximum) which is a feature seen more commonly at low latitudes. This is a result not seen previously because of low cadence and weak sensitivity of the FPI instrument utilized by Hernandez in the 70s which meant that the temperature variation of 50 to 100 degrees during the 90 minute period of the primary temperature peak would be difficult to discern.

     Another finding has been the relationship of the divergence observed in the neutral wind field to the poleward/westward passage of the midnight temperature maximum structure. As the tidal wind structure associated with the MTM structure  propagated from below into the upper region of the atmosphere, there is seen a phase lag between the reversal of the meridional wind component from southward to northward and the arrival of the thermal maximum into the 630-nm emission layer. This phase lag is seen as a convergence followed by a divergence as the wind direction rotates from southward to northward and then southward again.

     An additional interesting discovery coming out of the analysis of NATION FPI observations is the realization of the spectral contamination of FPI observations as a result of bright auroral arc forms located near the northern horizon. Looking south, as an example, it was possible to demonstrate that the signal seen in that direction might be contaminated by light from the northern sky scattered into the line-of-sight. Thus, the Doppler shift associated with the signal from the south direction is contaminated by a Doppler shift associated with the light from the north scattered into the field of view. This finding has meant that it is difficult to interpret the results associated with geomagnetic storm events.

     Through the support provided by a supplement award from the NSF Aeronomy program, it became possible to ship a Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI) instrument to Bahir Dar for a collaborative project with Prof. Baylie Damtie and a graduate student Mr. Fasil Tessema. The FPI instrument was constructed with the support provided by a DURIP award to Clemson University from the Air Force Office of Scientific Research. The results seen from these observations show the MTM structure as being quite dominant in the nighttime midnight period as expected from Brazil and Peru observations obtained several years previously. The results also showed that the zonal equatorial winds are generally 20-35 ms-1 weaker in the evening period near 20 to 23 LT than the winds seen in the American longitudinal sector.
